claim: Aretha Franklin could have voted for a president when her second child was born.

supporting.text: Aretha Franklin was born in 1942, making her 18 years old in 1960, the year her second child was born. The voting age in the U.S. was 21 at that time, but she could have voted in the 1964 presidential election when she was 22.

attacks.text: Aretha Franklin was born in 1942, making her 18 years old in 1960, the year her second child was born. The voting age in the U.S. was 21 at that time, but she could have voted in the 1964 presidential election when she was 22.
The claim specifies voting 'when her second child was born' (1960), not in 1964. Thus, the argument does not directly support the claim.
Aretha Franklin's second child was born in 1960, and she was not eligible to vote in any presidential election until 1964 due to the voting age being 21.
The argument correctly notes that she could have voted in 1964, which is relevant to her lifetime voting eligibility, even if not directly addressing the claim's timeframe.

supporting.text: The 26th Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18, was ratified in 1971. However, Franklin was already of voting age (21) by the time her second child was born in 1960, so she could have voted in subsequent elections.

attacks.text: The 26th Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18, was ratified in 1971. However, Franklin was already of voting age (21) by the time her second child was born in 1960, so she could have voted in subsequent elections.

The claim specifies voting 'when her second child was born' (1960), not 'subsequent elections.' Franklin could not have voted in 1960 because the 26th Amendment did not yet exist, and she was not yet 21.
Franklin turned 18 in 1960, but the voting age was 21 at the time. The 26th Amendment's retroactive lowering of the voting age does not apply to elections before its ratification.
Some states allowed voting at 18 before the 26th Amendment, but Franklin was born in Tennessee, which did not lower its voting age until 1971.

supporting.text: Aretha Franklin was a U.S. citizen and met the age requirement (21) by the time of the 1964 presidential election, which occurred after her second child was born in 1960.

attacks.text: Aretha Franklin was a U.S. citizen and met the age requirement (21) by the time of the 1964 presidential election, which occurred after her second child was born in 1960.
The Voting Rights Act of 1965 was not yet enacted in 1964, and many African Americans, including Aretha Franklin, faced systemic voter suppression in some states.
Aretha Franklin lived in Detroit, Michigan, where African American voter suppression was less severe compared to Southern states, increasing her likelihood of voting in 1964.
There is no public record of Aretha Franklin voting in the 1964 election, casting doubt on whether she actually voted despite eligibility.
Celebrities often avoid publicizing their political activities to maintain neutrality, so lack of voting records does not disprove participation.

supporting.text: Franklin's second child was born in 1960, and she turned 21 in 1963, making her eligible to vote in the 1964 presidential election, which was the next election after her child's birth.

attacks.text: Franklin's second child was born in 1960, and she turned 21 in 1963, making her eligible to vote in the 1964 presidential election, which was the next election after her child's birth.
The voting age in the U.S. was not lowered to 18 until 1971, so Franklin could not have voted in the 1964 election if she was only 21 in 1963.
Franklin was born in 1942, which means she turned 21 in 1963, making her eligible to vote in the 1964 election under the voting laws at that time.
Even if Franklin was eligible to vote in 1964, there is no evidence that she actually registered or voted in that election.

supporting.text: Historical records show that Aretha Franklin was politically active later in life, suggesting she likely exercised her right to vote when she became eligible after her second child's birth.

attacks.text: Historical records show that Aretha Franklin was politically active later in life, suggesting she likely exercised her right to vote when she became eligible after her second child's birth.
Political activity later in life does not necessarily imply voting behavior at an earlier stage, especially given the societal barriers faced by Black women in the mid-20th century.
Voter registration records from Franklin's county of residence during that time period show no evidence of her being registered.
Absence of records does not prove non-registration, as many historical documents from that era were poorly maintained or lost.
Franklin's touring schedule during election years suggests she may have been unable to vote due to being out of state.
Absentee voting was available in most states by the time Franklin would have been eligible to vote.
